text.q: "Paul, an apostle of Christ Jesus through the will of God, and Timothy our brother,
to the holy ones in Colossae—those who are faithful brothers and sisters in Christ: Grace to you and peace from God our Father.
We always give thanks to the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ when we pray for you,
because we have heard of your faith in Christ Jesus and the love you have for all the holy ones.
This faith and love spring from the hope stored up for you in the heavens, which you first heard about in the word of truth—the Good News
that has come to you. Just as it is bearing fruit and growing in all the world, it is doing the same among you from the day you heard it and truly came to know the grace of God in truth.
You learned this from Epaphras, our beloved fellow-slave, who is a faithful servant of the Christ on our behalf,
and who has made known to us your love in the Spirit.

Because of this, from the day we heard about it, we have not stopped praying for you. We ask that you may be filled with the deep knowledge of his will, through all spiritual wisdom and understanding,
so that you may walk in a way worthy of the Lord, seeking to please him in everything. We pray that you will bear fruit in every good work and grow in the deep knowledge of God,
being strengthened with all power according to his glorious might, resulting in absolute endurance and patience. With joy,
give thanks to the Father, who has qualified you for a share in the inheritance of the holy ones in the light.
He rescued us from the dominion of darkness and transferred us into the kingdom of the Son of his love,
in whom we have release through ransom, the forgiveness of sins.
He is the visible image of the invisible God, the firstborn heir over all creation.

For in him all things were created—in the heavens and on the earth, the visible and the invisible, whether thrones or lordships or rulers or authorities—all things have been created through him and for him.
He exists before all things, and in him all things are held together.
He is the head of the body, the ekklesia; he is the beginning, the firstborn from the dead, so that in everything he might be preeminent.
For in him all the Fullness was pleased to make its home,
and through him to reconcile all things to himself—whether things on earth or things in the heavens—by making peace through the blood of his cross.
And you, who were once alienated and hostile in your mind because of your wicked deeds,
he has now reconciled in his body of flesh through death, to present you holy, blameless, and irreproachable before him.

This holds true if you continue in the faith, established and firm, not shifting from the hope of the Good News that you heard, which has been proclaimed to every creature under heaven, and of which I, Paul, became a servant.
Now I rejoice in my sufferings for your sake, and in my flesh I am filling up what is lacking in the afflictions of the Christ for the sake of his body, which is the ekklesia.
I became its servant according to the stewardship from God given to me for you, to fulfill the word of God—
the sacred secret that was hidden for ages and generations, but has now been revealed to his holy ones.
To them God chose to make known how great among the nations is the riches of the glory of this sacred secret, which is Christ in you, the hope of glory.
He is the one we proclaim, warning everyone and teaching everyone with all wisdom, so that we may present everyone mature in Christ.
For this I labor, struggling with all his energy that works so powerfully within me."

verse.text: For I want you to know how great a wrestling match I am enduring for you, and for those in Laodicea, and for all those who have never seen my face in the flesh.
My goal is that their hearts may be encouraged, interwoven in love and led into all the riches of the full assurance of insight, resulting in a deep recognition of the mystery of God—namely, Christ.
In him are hidden all the treasures of wisdom and knowledge.
I say this so that no one may delude you with persuasive but hollow rhetoric.
For even though I am physically absent, I am with you in spirit, rejoicing as I observe your orderly formation and the solid bulwark of your faith in Christ.
Therefore, just as you received Christ Jesus the Lord, continue to walk in him,
having been firmly rooted and now being built up in him, established in the faith just as you were taught, and overflowing with thankfulness.
Watch out so that no one carries you off as plunder through "philosophy" and empty deceit, according to human tradition and the elemental powers of the world, rather than according to Christ.
For in him, the entire fullness of the Divine Nature resides in a physical body,
and you have been brought to fullness in him, who is the head over every ruler and authority.
In him you were also circumcised with a circumcision performed without hands, by the stripping off of the body of the flesh, by the circumcision of Christ.
You were buried with him in baptism, in which you were also raised with him through faith in the operative power of God, who raised him from the dead.
And you, though you were dead in your trespasses and the uncircumcision of your flesh, he made alive together with him—graciously forgiving us all our trespasses.
He erased the signed record of debt that stood against us with its regulations—the one that was hostile to us—and has taken it out of the way, nailing it to the cross.
Having stripped the rulers and authorities, he made a public spectacle of them, leading them in a victory parade in him.
Therefore, do not let anyone act as your judge regarding eating or drinking, or in respect to a festival, a New Moon, or Sabbaths.
These are a shadow of the things to come, but the substance belongs to Christ.
Let no one cheat you of your prize by delighting in self-abasement and the worship of angels, dwelling on visions they have seen, puffed up without cause by their own fleshly mind.
Such a person does not hold fast to the Head, from whom the whole body—nourished and knit together through its joints and ligaments—grows with a growth that is from God.
If you died with Christ to the elemental powers of the world, why, as if you were still living in the world, do you submit to regulations—
"Do not handle, do not taste, do not touch"—
all of which refer to things destined to perish with use? These are based on human commands and teachings.
These things have a reputation for wisdom, with their self-made religion, self-abasement, and severe treatment of the body, but they are of no value in restraining the indulgence of the flesh.
If, then, you were raised with the Christ, seek the things above, where the Christ is, seated at the right hand of God.
Set your minds on the things above, not on the things upon the earth.
For you died, and your life has been hidden with the Christ in God.
When the Christ—who is your life—is revealed, then you also will be revealed with him in glory.
Put to death, then, your earthly members: sexual immorality, impurity, lust, evil desire, and greed—which is idolatry.
Because of these things, the wrath of God is coming upon those who are characterized by disobedience.
You also once walked in these ways when you were living in them.
But now, you must also lay aside all these things: anger, rage, malice, slander, and shameful speech from your mouth.
Do not lie to one another, since you have stripped off the old humanity with its practices
and have put on the new humanity, which is being renewed into full knowledge according to the image of its Creator.
In this state, there is no Greek and Jew, circumcised and uncircumcised, barbarian, Scythian, slave, or free; instead, Christ is all things and in all things.
Therefore, as God’s chosen ones, holy and beloved, dress yourselves with deep-seated compassion, kindness, humility, gentleness, and patience.
Bear with one another and be gracious to each other if anyone has a complaint against someone else; just as the Lord was gracious to you, so you must also be.
Above all these things, put on love, which is the bond of completeness.
And let the peace of Christ act as the umpire in your hearts, the peace to which you were called in one body. And be thankful.
Let the word of the Christ dwell within you richly as you teach and admonish one another in all wisdom, singing psalms, hymns, and spiritual songs with grace in your hearts to God.
And whatever you do, whether in word or in deed, do everything in the name of the Lord Jesus, giving thanks to God the Father through him.
Wives, align yourselves under your husbands, as is fitting in the Lord.
Husbands, love your wives and do not be embittered against them.
Children, obey your parents in everything, for this is pleasing in the Lord.
Fathers, do not irritate your children, so they do not become discouraged.
Slaves, obey your earthly masters in everything—not with performative service as people-pleasers, but with sincerity of heart, fearing the Lord.
Whatever you do, work from the soul, as for the Lord and not for humans,
knowing that from the Lord you will receive the repayment of the inheritance. You are serving the Lord Christ.
For the one who does wrong will be paid back for the wrong he did, and there is no partiality.
Masters, provide justice and equality to your slaves, knowing that you also have a Master in heaven.
Devote yourselves to prayer, staying alert in it with thanksgiving.
At the same time, pray also for us, that God may open a door for the word, so that we may speak the secret of the Christ—for which I have been bound in chains—
so that I may make it clear, as is necessary for me to speak.
Conduct yourselves with wisdom toward those on the outside, purchasing every opportune moment.
Let your speech always be gracious, seasoned with salt, so that you may know how you ought to answer each individual person.
Tychicus, my beloved brother, faithful ministering servant, and fellow-slave in the Lord, will make all my affairs known to you.
I have sent him to you for this very purpose: so that you may know how we are and that he may encourage your hearts.
He is coming with Onesimus, our faithful and beloved brother, who is one of your own. They will inform you about everything here.
Aristarchus, my fellow prisoner-of-war, sends you greetings, as does Mark, the cousin of Barnabas (concerning whom you received instructions—if he comes to you, welcome him),
and Jesus, who is called Justus. These are the only ones of the circumcision who are my co-workers for the kingdom of God, and they have been a source of comfort to me.

Epaphras, who is one of your own and a slave of Christ, sends you greetings. He is always wrestling on your behalf in his prayers, so that you may stand mature and fully assured in everything that God wills.
For I testify for him that he has worked with great pain for you and for those in Laodicea and Hierapolis.
Luke, the beloved physician, sends you greetings, as does Demas.
Greet the brothers and sisters in Laodicea, and also Nympha and the assembly that meets in her house.
When this letter has been read among you, arrange for it to be read also in the assembly of the Laodiceans, and see that you also read the letter coming from Laodicea.
And say to Archippus: "Pay attention to the ministry that you received in the Lord, so that you may fulfill it."
This greeting is in my own hand—Paul’s. Remember my chains. Grace be with you.
